div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.
Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m.

for Port Sudan and Soakin direct returning from Soakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6pm A steamer leave Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Soakin, Mesowah, Hodeidab, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.

The weather during the past week has been very warm and seasonable. The feeling of oppressiveness however has been relived by a nor' westerly breeze which has continued to blow and is still blowing. To-day the glass shows a tendency to rise.

SATURDAY, JULY 7, 1906.

div.head: EGYPTIAN UNREST
div.p: Sir Edward Grey has spoken, and his speech may be fairly said to express what many Anglo-Egyptians have thought for months past and have not dared to express, through a fear of seeming to be afraid. The situation has become unpleasant since the demonstration of the allied fleets at Mitylene resulted in the despatch to Egypt of a force of agents-provocateurs, and in our opinion, Sir Edward Grey has done well to treat it seriously. It may be objected that there is no evidence for the increase throughout North Africa of "religious" movement aiming at the expulsion of foreigners. We cannot speak with any authority of the state of affairs in Algeria and Tanis; we only know that in the last-named province some anxiety has been caused by the proceedings of the numerous Moslem fraternities, especially the powerful Madani sect Morocco is, of course, opposed to European interference of any sort, and it may be taken for granted that the wild tribes of the Sahara are, as ever, the enemies of all that stands for civilization and settled government. From Tripoli comes the news that the Turkish Government has forbidden the interior to European explorers and travelers, and that a movement in making way in Fezzan, Baron, and Tripoli proper aiming at an understanding between the Turkish rulers and the Arab and Kabyle fraternities of the province.

In Egypt, we have witnessed the first and we wish we could hope the last stirrings of a Pan-Islamic movement. The outbreaks at Alexandria, the violent and unchecked tirades of the "Nationalist" Press, the direction of school strikes by agitators, the frontier dispute with its train of consequences, the increase of the Army of Occupation and the ultimatum to Turkey, the appeals made to the Egyptian Army by the most fanatical of the Nationalist journals, the painful incident at Danishwai, and the agitation to which it gave rise, bare made the year interesting if agitated. But however pleasant it may be for a journalist to feel that at last something is happening in an upoventful country, his pleasure is not abared by the official, the businessman, and the trader, and indeed by all the stable elements of Egyptian society. They want no disturbances and no agitation, and whatever their sympathies, they are likely to be reassured by Sir B. Grey's statement that Great Britain is prepared, should the necessity arise, to support the local authorities by means that may be perforce unconstitutional.

We commend Sir E. Gray's speech to those who by daily tirades are doing their best to excite ill-feeling tetween Egyptians and the subjeots of the occupying Power, and to that ignoble if less dangerous class which insults Europeans when in a large majority, toasts the Denishwai criminals, and in it, every action shows itself "willing to wound" but very much "afraid to strike." To the Pan-Islamic Press it gives a warning that the role of agent provocateur may one day prove dangerous. To those who desire a revival of the days of Ismail and Arabi, it opposes the inflexible determination of the British people to preserve the nascent civilisation of Egypt from the forces of shiftless barbarism and medieval bigotry.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail.
div.p: The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Monday.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: The imports of coal from January 1 to July 5 amounted to 617,619 tons, as compared to 471,801 tons during the same period last year.

div.head: Military Prison, Cairo.
div.p: During the absence on leave of Major A. S. Cave, Acting Governor, Military Prison, Cairo, his duties will be performed by Major H. M. Finch, 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, till the return of Major B. M. K. Parsons, Governor, Military Prison, Cairo.

div.head: Law School Fees
div.p: The Ministry of Public Instruction intends to raise to the teaching fees in the Khedivial Law School, Cairo, to L.E. 30 per annum for new scholars, but the old pupils of the same school will not have to pay any extra fee.

div.head: Land Purchase.
div.p: Mr. Nassim Affif, of Cairo, bus purchased a large plot of land situated in the best part of Tantah, in the Sharia Nouzha. He intends to divide the land up into small lots of 400 to 500 sq. metres, so as to place them within reach of small purchasers. The land covers an area of close on 100,000 sq. metres.

div.head: Telephone Complaints
div.p: We have heard so much of the irregularities of the telephone service at Alexandria that the public will welcome an innovation which has been introduced by the Telephone Compay, in the shape of complaint postcards. A number of these have been issued to each subscriber, who will thus have simple and convenient means of bringing complaints before the management, who are always ready to redress any grievance.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Today's plague bulletin records no fresh cases. We are informed, however, that the 5-year old daughter of Mr. Antonio Pelioi, a British Maltese subject living in Attarin-street, died in hospital yesterday evening from what was certified by the doctor in attendance to be bubonic plague. The little girl was attacked three days ago, and was removed to hospital about 6 o'clook yesterday, but succumbed within a few minutes of being admitted.

div.head: Alhamora Theatre
div.p: The Lombardo operetta company brings its seasons at Alexandria to close to-morrow evening with a performance of The Geisha. On Monday the company proceeds to Cairo and will pen on Tuesday evening at the Abbas Theatre with the same piece, which will no doubt meet with the same success as here. The boards of the Alhambra will be occupied on Monday by the Castellano opera company in La Tosca.

div.head: The Mex Outrage
div.p: The third native implicated in the assault on Private George O'Brien at Mex on Monday night has not yet been arrested, but the police believe they are on his track. The trial of the ac cused will take place in the Native Tribunals, the case being considered as an ordinary one of assault. A rumor was current in town yesterday that Private O'Brien had succumbed to his injuries at Rass el Tin Hospital, but we are lad to learn on enquiry that he is as well as can be expected under the circumstances. The rumour arose from the fact that another patient in the hospital died, and as the gun carriage conveying his body to the cemetery passed through the main streets the mistaken conclusion was arrived at that the Mex incident had ended fatally, which happily is not the case.

div.head: Sheapheards.
div.p: Advantage is being taken of the quiet summer months by the directors of Shepboard's Hotel to add to and considerably improve this popular hostelry. The addition of a third floor which is at present being built will provide accommodation for nearly a hundred extra guests. This floor will include besides the bedrooms, twenty-two bathrooms with lavatories, etc. The grill-room is being enlarged by the addition of the space hitherto given over to the garden terrace, and from this will be built another large terrace, five metres in width, while a new corridor is being constructed on as to connect it directly with the kitchens, Another great improvement is the addition of the extra nine metres to the large mi in dining-room. A distinct improvement will also be made in the present offices of the directors and a small part of the ladies' drawing room will be converted into the manager's office. A large lift is being constructed for visitors and a small one for luggage so that the hotel will in future be provided with three lifts instead of only one. On the new third story two spacious, cupola-shaped balconies are being built.

div.head:
BRITISH FOREIGN POLICY
IMPORTANT SPEECH BY SIR E. GREY.
THE ANGLO-JAPANESE ALLIANCE.
THE CONGO QUESTION.
GREAT BRITIAN AND RUSSIA.

div.p: HOUSE, OF COMMONS -Sir E. Grey, in an important statement on the foreign policy of the Government, emphasized the value, and unaggressive character, of the alliance with Japan and the entente with France. The latter, be said, would be unimpaired by other developments of Great Britain's policy. He reminded King Leopold that other people had rights in the Congo. Ho distrusted the efficacy of the projected reforms and said that Britain would readily join with other Powers in pressing for a change of the system of government, but, in view of the remarkable and welcome change in the attitude of the Belgian Parliament and people, and the desirability of Belgium taking over the Congo, be preferred to wait before committing the Government to any definite steps.

He justified the visit of the Fleet to Kronstadt and said that it would be exceedingly inappropriate not to visit the Russian porta in the Baltic which had not been visited in 1905. He was in possession of trustworthy information to the effect that the Russian Central Government had not connived at the massacres.

The visit was arranged long since, entirely without reference to Russian affairs, in a friendly spirit to the Tsar, the Russian Government, and people. He cannot imagine the Duma interpreting the visit as our taking sides, which would appear to be the case if we now abandoned it. In his opinion, the only safe role with regard to Russian troubles was to avoid comment or interference.
(Reuter)

HOUSE OF COMMONS -In last nights' debate on Foreign Policy Sir E. Grey said that the Japanese Alliance was enjoying "exceedingly good health." Japan was devoting her remarkable energy and public spirit to guiding Korea, and to the development of her own resources. The Alliance gives a sense of mutual security to each without being of serious anxiety to anybody else. He trusted that it would long remain so.
(Reuter)

Sir E. Grey, Signor Tittoni, and M Cambon have agreed to the draft arrangement concerning Abyssinia, but the arrangement would not be signed until the Emperor Menelik expressed his views thereon, nor published until it became definite
(Reuter)
The Poles have decided to kill every one of the police if the state of siege is not raised.
(Havas)
The trial of Rodjestvenaky has commenced. The Admiral is defending himself.
(Havas)
In his defense, Dreyfas's counsel showed that there was nothing in any of the accusations.
(Havas)
The Conference has signed the revised Convention.
(Havas)
The Budget Commission has been elected. It has appointed M. Barteaux as president.
General Meckel, German organiser of the Japanese army, is dead.
(Reuter)
Cricket. Notts beat Yorkshire by 25 runs. Lancashire best Gloucestershire by an innings and 29 runs.
(Reuter)

div.head:
FANATICISM IN EGYPT
Sensational Speech in the Commons
Sir E. Greys Appeal
The Meaning of Denishwai
div.p: Sir E. Grey begged the House not to pass a hasty judgment with regard to the Danishwai executions and not to embark on a discussion of such a serious subject at present. He emphasized the fact of the newspaper reports of the executions being inaccurate and deprecated any unfairness towards Egyptian officials, whom he eulogised. What was more serious was that all this year fanaticism in Egypt had been increasing and was not confined to Egypt alone, but was spreading throughout the North of Africa. The attack on British officers would never have occurred a little while ago. Since this attack, other significant attacks had been made on Europeans. "We may be on the eve of farther measures necessary for the protection of Europeans in Egypt, and, if the House at this moment weakens or destroys the authority of the Egyptian Government, you will be face to face with a most serious situation, because, if fanaticism in Egypt overcomes the authority of the Egyptian Government, extreme measures will be necessary. We may be forced at any moment to take unconstitutional measures which we should be bound to take in an emergency." Sir E.Grey's speech created a profound sensation and was listened to in silence, broken only by occasional approving cheers. Mr. Keir Hardie said that in view of the Foreign Secretary's appeal, he would not diss the matter further. Lord Cromer was present during the debate.
(Reuter)

In view of Sir Edward Grey's speech, the remarks of the "Daily Telegraph" in reference to the Danishwai affair are extremely à propos. Our London contemporary says:-" Peculiar interest and significance attached to this care, which intrinsically might be regarded as being of merely local importance, by reason of the subterranean unrest in Egypt, which has been recorded for some month past by the politico-seismological machine at Cairo. There is no doubt a considerable section of Egyptians who would strengthen Turkish influence at the expense of English in the territories of the Khedive. The increase of the Imperial forces in the Khediviate when the Akabah crisis threatened to become acute was due, not to fear of anything the Sultan might do, but to our knowledge of the excitement aroused in the minds of the Egyptians by the crisis itself. The danger, such as it was added another proof that amongst Oriental religious fanaticism is apt to override all considerations of material advantage and prosperity. The same phenomenon was accountable for the troubles in Morocco. Bat the fast is more strange in Egypt. The fellah has had an experience of government by Turkish pashas; under their role, he was ill-treated, compelled to labour without wages on works unproductive as well as productive, in which he had no personal interest, lived under a hopelessly corrupt judicial system, which cared for no law but that of "backsheesh "; he was miserably poor, the prey of the greediest moneylenders in the world, and had about as miserable an existence as fell to the lot of any semi-civilized creature. England and Lord Cromer have changed all that. The corvée is abolished, the kourbash has, except for criminals, no longer any terrors; justice is administered with stern impartiality; taxes have been reduced to as nearly a minimum as possible; the credit of the country is as good at that of the wealthiest Power in Europe; irrigation, which supplies the bread of life to the dwellers on the Nile, has been extended to a degree undreamt of by the most enterprising Pharaohs, and all the resources of the country are being developed marvelously, largely by the assistance of British capital, which would have hardly been forthcoming had not the City and the capitalist had unbounded confidence in Lord Cromer's wisdom and administrative genius. Yet it cannot be denied that amongst the classes most favored by our protectorate there are some whose fanaticism blinds them to their own interest as well as to the general regeneration of their ancient country; men who would rather starve under the profligate extravagance of a Mursalman Ismail than live in plenty provided by the wide counsels of an English Christian. There can be no doubt that Turkish intrigue has been pushed very far whether by the Sultan himself or by dangerous advisers there is no means of determining. This much, however, is certain that since Russia's failure in the Far East and the beginning of her domestic difficulties, Abdul Hamid has divested himself of that daily and nightly terror with which the power of his nearest neighbor inspired him. But the Saltan is a man of great experience and great cunning, and know that today, in spite of all the alleged disaffection in the Russian army and navy, the Tear, if he were so disposed, could sweep down on Constantinople and pluck it like a ripe fruit. He knows that Russia is on better terms with England than she has ever been and that just as she has always disavowed in her happy times-any particular interest in Egypt, it is notorious that England would not move a gunboat to save Constantinople for the Turks. These considerations should give pause to that anti-English party in Egypt which has always been feeble, and which since the conclusion of the Anglo-French convention has become utterly hopeless.

div.head:
Death of Col. Sparkes.
A Gallant and Capable Officer.
div.p: Colonel William Spottiswoode Sparkes Bey, C. M. G., in dead The deceased served in the Dongola expeditionary force in 1896 and was decorated for his services in Egypt, where he is well-known. By his death the country has been deprived of the services of a gallant and capable officer.

div.head: The Boundary Commission
div.p: In political circles in Constantinople, so we are informed by our correspondent, an agreement regarding the frontier is considered as impossible in view of the opposition which exists between the working of the one and the other commission.

div.head: Trouble in Store
div.p: The"Berliner Neueste Nachrichten" concludes an article entitled "The Saltan in his African Vilayet," which deals with the Pan-Islamic revival in North Africa and the recent Turko Egyptian Frontier Question, by the following remarks:-"Itis likely enough that the Senoussi Mahdi and his fanatical adherents are about to make their presence felt. At present a movement, which should be veiled, is manifesting itself openly in Tripoli. The fact at least that the Ottoman Government has ordered the authorities of Tripoli and Benghazi to refuse the usual permits to travel in the interior to foreign explorers and travellers, seems conclusive as to this point. All this is food for thought, the more so at a moment when news comes of disturbances in the Sudan which, despite official assurances, may not be purely local in their character."

div.head: Inflammatory Newspapers
div.p: "Al Mokattam's" correspondent in Alexandria writes to his paper to the effect that enlightened natives are of opinion that the recent attack against a British soldier by some natives of a very low class at Mex was mostly due to inflammatory tirades of a section of the native Press.

A native notable says, continues the writer, that the English will not be quite justified in punishing ignorant and low-class people for crimes inspired by misleading newspapers, and leaving their guides unpunished. The former are blind, the latter their guides, and the mischievous newspapers which they edit should be suppressed. Egypt, remarks the writer, is the only country in the world where the ignorant and uncultured are allowed to publish "rags" which they call newspapers, and which they use to acquire money by blackmail. The publishers of such misleading papers, which can produce nothing but ignorance and inaccuracy, are not, really, to be blamed for their errors, which are natural as long as they are themselves uneducated and unpolished. The British occupants of Egypt are alone responsible for the effects of the misleading or mischievous statements that always appear in those papers.

div.head: The Callicopoulo Affair
div.p: Dr. J. Kérassotis has addressed a long letter to a Cairo contemporary describing the condition of the servant girl Irene whom he was called in to attend after her torture by Callicopoulor and attempting to explain his failure to warn the authorities. This admirable physician writes : "According to French medical law, which I studied, a doctor is not obliged to warn the authorities of a case of crime or cruelty but is free to act in accordance with the dictates of his own conscience. I was therefore under no obligation to inform the Hellonio Consulate; nor is it fair to state that I neglect ed to give information, since, on visiting the house next morning. I found the consular authorities there, none of whom could give spy opinion as to my decision whether to denounce or not to denounce the guilty parties. It is not true that the girl was taken to hospital after 10 days' illness. She was carried to Dr. Milton's hospital on the day of my diagnosis."
Dr. Kérassotis concludes with a peroration concerning the duties of his profession.

div.head: Alexandria Native Court
div.p: At this morning's sitting of the Alexandria Native Court, Abdel Meghid Attiah Mohamed, of Maiuieh, Behera, was sentenced to three years imprisonment for having kidnapped one of his pieces, a girl of four years, with the object of extorting money from his brother.
A Greek grocer's boy, local subject, was sent to prison for six months for having committed an indecent assault on a native girl of seven years.

div.head: Turkish Coal
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir,- After noting all that Shipping Agent" writes about Turkish coals in your issue of yesterday, would he kindly inform me through the medium of your valuable paper if the price of 10s, mentioned by him is F. O. B. or C. if. as unless it is the latter I am afraid cheaper coal can be had from England. He does not mention what the shipping facilities aro.-Yours, etc.,
COAL IMPORTER.

div.head: STEAMER Movements
div.p: The S.S. Asiatic Prince left Malta on the 6th inst., and is due at Alexandria on Monday.

div.head:
The Khedive
Rumoured Pilgrimage to Mecca
div.p: No little stir has been created among political circles at Stamboul, writes our Copatantinople Correspondent, by the report that H.H. the Khedive would make a hadjilik to Mecca.
Such a visit would be sure to complicate the already vexed question of the Khalifate, and we publish the news under every reserve.

div.head: The Tripoli Question
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent states that a rumor is current there that the Italian Government intends sending a cruiser to Tripoli in order to press its claims for an indemnity, in favour of the Italian merchants who suffered loss in property during the recent disturbances.

div.head: Constanza-Alexandria Line
div.p: The Roumanian Foreign Minister, in concert with the Minister of Public Works, has commenced pourparlers with the Egyptian authorities, and has issued to Mr. Al. Pacleanou, the new Romanian Consul General at Cairo, the necessary instructions, in regard to the establishment of the direct sea-route between Constanza and Alexandria

div.head: Ports and Lights. Report for 1905.
div.p: The Administration of Ports and Lighthouses has just issued its report for 1905 on the shipping movement at Alexandria, Port Said and, Suez. It is replete with statistics, and, inter alia, contains the following returns :

During 1905, 1,817 steamers and 2,794 sailing ships entered the harbor of Alexandria, as against 1,731 and 2,290 respectively in 1904. The steamers represented a total tonnage of 3,296,237 tons and the sailing ships 295,044, as against 2,982,294 and 225,697 tons respectively in 1904.

The number of vessels passing through the Canal was 4,135, or a net tonnage of 11,539,989. Of these 2,494 were British, of 7,318,001 tons. Germany comes next with 597 vessels of 1,793,869 tons ; then France with 273 ships of 757,882 tons.
In 1904 the transit was 4,259 and tonnage 11,570,413 ; in 1903, 3,778 and 10,300,257.

The number of steamers calling at Port Said without entering the Canal was 917, and that of sailing-ships 910, a general total of 1,379,846 tons of these, 486 were British, 130 French, 76 Austrian, and 36 Italian.
At Suez, during 1905, there called 268 steamers, as against 182 in 1904. The total tonnage in 1905 was 285,489.48.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Regent, is leaving for Europe today.
De Martino Pasha, director-general of the Daira Khassa, has returned to Cairo from Europe.
Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, second secretary to the Ministry of the Interior, has left for Europe.
Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo City Police, will leave for England on the 15th inst.

A board of officers is to meet at the Military Hospital, Alexandria, in a day or two, to examine and report on the present state of health of Capt. and Brevet Major Pine-Coffin, D. S. O., Royal North Lancashire Regiment (M. I.). We are sorry to learn that it has not been so satisfactory of late.
Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Carey are leaving for England on Monday next.
Rev. W. Jackson, A. C. D., has been granted three months' leave of absence.
Lieut. H. S. Willson, A. O. D. leaves for England by the Bibby Line S. S. Worcestershire on Tuesday next from Port Said.

div.head: Egyptian Prosperity
div.p: Mr. W. M. S. Selwyn, of the Commercial Intelligence Bureau, writes to the "Globe":- "In reference to the very interesting 'City Notas' on the prosperity of Egypt, which we must have made their proper impression in financial circles, it may be suggested that it is of the highest importance for British capital to be employed to the fullest possible extent in the development of this land of riches, and to prevent foreign speculators securing an Influence in the country which might be to our political disadvantage later on. The question is-is the profitable exploitation of Egypt to fell to the British, who have risked so much here, or to the French, the Germans, the Italians, and the Greeks, all of whom would Constitute foreign element which, there is Ivory reason to believe, might seriously harass British rule. We have already had experience of anti-British intriguer in the country, and it is incumbent upon us to secure that in the future we shall have an unquestioned predominance over all other European nationalities. It happens, fortunately, that the fulfillment of this desirable political object requires no heroic political measures, but simply the application to the problem of an enterprising commercial spirit. Let the fruitful lands of the Delta be in British, not foreign, hands. This would add stability to the British occupation, and at the same time pay money into British pockets."

div.head: Promotion of Hellenic Studies
div.p: Professor Percy Gardner presided last week at the annual meeting of the Society for the Promotion of Hellenic Studies, held at Burlington House. The report read by Mr. George A. Macmillan, the hon. secretary referred to the loss sustained by the society in the death of the late President, Sir Richard Claverhouse Jebb. An important departure in the constitution was the creation of Student Associates. The Council had long felt that there was a class of younger students specially interested in the objects of the society, and by inclination and training likely to be useful members, who were debarred owing to the entrance fee from coming forward as candidates. Professor Gardner in his address spoke of the progress made in recent discoveries in that branch of Hellenic learning which is concerned with the remains of ancient Greece. He pointed out that although excavations had proceeded many Greek sites such as Ephesus, Lindys, Pergamus, and Miletus, striking discoveries had been few. The discoveries at ancient Sparta, made by Mr. Bosanquet and his colleagues at the British School at Athens, gave great hope for the future, and this place had now been made over to the English as a place of research, The Athenino Acropolis was dearest to them as phil Hellenes. During the year that sacred site had somewhat changed its appearance through the partial restoration of the Erechtheium. No question had been more discussed in archeological circles than the propriety of rebuilding the partly surviving temples of Greece. The Parthenon had only been repaired to prevent its falling, but the question was not whether more pillars should be set up, but whether some of the sculptured freize which still remained in situ should be removed and placed in the museum since it seemed to be perishing from the action of the climate. Professor Garder was elected president for five years, and Mr. Caoil Snith, Keeper of the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities in the British Museum, gave an illustrated communication on the pediments of the Parthenon.

div.head: Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.
div.p: "Weary and Ill at Ease"
The Lady Orcanist Swooned.
Life a Martyrdom from Anemia.
So Weak, Bloodless and Miserable.
With Dizziness and Acute Indigestion.
Is Now Strong, Cheerful, and Well. Health Fully Restored.

A PATHETIC incident arose on one occasion at a church in Longton, Staff, when the lady organist suddenly collapsed at service and fell in a swoon. That event was recalled at an interview which press representative recently had with the lady, Mrs. J. Made'ey. who resides at 45, Dunrobin-street, Longton.

"The incident," she stated, "was the result of ill-health, and though it occurred some years ago I still have vivid recollections of my sufferings. I suffered from acute indigestion with great pain after meals, and a sense of oppression like choking.

"I dieted myself and ate less and less, yet every morsel of, food punished me severely. I sought medical advice, but to me it seemed only a waste of money. Then came shooting pains between my shoulders and down my back. My body never seemed free from pain. If I went upstairs or walked up a bill my heart would beat furiously. For months I was never without throbbing pains of neuralgia in my head. I seemed to be in a maze all day long. I had continual noises in the ears, with attacks of dizziness and faintness. Through deficiency of blood, I lost energy. Tired and languid by day, and without rest at night, I became painfully weak.

"One day while at the church organ, I was overcome with an attack of dizziness and fainted away. I was taken out into the fresh air, and there recovered from the swoon, but for a long time, I felt the effects of this. Eventually, my life became a daily martyrdom; weak and bloodless from anemia and racked by pains, I was a picture of misery and helplessness.
"Luckily a friend earnestly advised me to try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, so I purchased

A box, and before long was surprised to find myself more cheerful and taking an interest in life. As I continued the pills my food nourished me. I would feel the glow of new life in my body. I slept soundly at night; the pains disappeared, my appetite increased, and health came back. Soon I was quite well again. My eyes were bright, my complexion clear, and I was strong."

div.head: THE Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Hall No. 43, Winchester Honse, Old Broad Street, in the City of London on Thursday, the 19th day of July 1906, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolutions, or Resolofions to a similar effect. If Resolutions 1 to 9 inclusive should be passed by the requisite majority, they will be submitted for confirmation to a subsequent General Meeting to be hereafter convened so as to become Special Resolutions.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS
div.p: That the Memorandum and Articles of Association be varied as follows :

1. By striking out from Section 3, subsection (a) of the Memorandum of Association the words "in any district" and by substituting for the words "in which the Railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve" occurring in the same subsection the words "or in the Sudan."
2. That Article 75 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by striking out the words, commencing "and every exercise of the power" down to the end of that Article.
3. That Article 81 be altered by striking out the words "or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
4. That Article 85 be altered by striking out the words "provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any Contract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
5. That Article 86 be altered by striking out all words after the words "shall be vacant."
6. That Article 87 be altered by striking out the words "save as aforesaid" appearing in the first line of such Article

7. That Article 89 be struck out and that there be substituted therefor the following Article : "The remuneration of the Directors "shall be the sum of £250 per annum to "each of the Directors and £500 per "annum to the Chairman, and such "remuneration shall be deemed to accrue "de die in diem. The remuneration shall "be exclusive of the sums, if any, which "under the provisions of these Presents "Director on account of special services."
8. That Article 20 be altered by striking out the words "provided he be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited."
9. That Article 96 be altered by striking out the words "one Director" and substituting therefor the words "two Directors."
10. That the Capital of the Company be increased from £250,000 to £500,000.

11. That the Memoradum of Agreement between the Company and the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, now submitted to the Meeting and initialled by the Chairman for the purposes of identification be approved and authorised to be entered into (subject to such alterations as the Board may think fit), and that the Board be authorised to enter into such further or other agreements as they may consider desirable for carrying such Memorandum of Agreement into effect.
By Order of the Board,
P.J. HORNE, Secretary

Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, i.e., not later than the 16th July, or with the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, or Alexandria ten clear days before the date of the Meeting, i.e., not later than 7th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting.

Copies of two circular letters issued to the Registered Shareholders with this Notice may be obtained upon application at the Offices of the Company, 211-214, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E. C, or from the National Bank of Egypt, Caire or Alexandria, Egypt.

div.head: Egyptian Trust and Investment.
Amalgamation With The Building Lands Company Agreed To...
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the members of the Egyptian Trust and Investment, Limited, was held on the 26th June last, at the ball of the Institute of Chartered Accountants, Moorgate-place, E.C, for the purpose of considering a proposed amalgamation with the "Building Lands of Egypt." Mr. R. Logan occupied the chair.
The Secretary (Mr. George T. Broadbridge) having had the notice convening the meeting,

The Chairman said: Before I begin my remarks I should inform you that my presence in the chair to-day is owing to the severe and protracted illness of our chairman, Sir Walter Beller. I am sure you will all sympathize with him in the prolonged illness from which he is pa suffering I should also mention that Mr. Clarles Cammell, a director, whose name appeared on the prospectus, died about fifteen months ago very shortly after the issue, and his place has not been filled up. The notice of meeting which has been issued to all the shareholders, and which has inst been read to you, will explain the object of our meeting. The only matter that has not been dealt with in the notice in any detail is the proposed scheme of amalgamation. This is fully dealt with in the contract of sale, referred to in the first resolution, and which the company's solicitor will presently read and explain. I will, however, shortly narrate to you some particulars concerning the object of this meeting. You are aware this company was floated about fifteen months ago, and that it was a phenomenal success. Of the issue of 200,000 shares, 150,000 were allotted to Egyptian shareholders, who were by far the largest applicants, and 50,000 were allotted in this country. The majority of the shares allotted in this country have since gradually passed into the hands of Egyptian shareholders. In every case, I believe, they have been purchased by Egyptian shareholders at a very considerable premium; and I am under the impression that at the present time there are not more than 15,000 shares held in this country altogether, out of the total issue of 206,000 shares. This company from time to time, with the assistance of its advisory board in Alexandria, has invested its money in the purchase of lands in Alexandria and has also invested a considerable amount of money in the Tramways Company of Alexandria. We are informed that at the present time the result of our purchase shows an estimated profit of not very much short of £130,000. That is the opinion of our advisory board in Egypt; but that, of course, is purely an estimate. At the present time, it would be a most unfortunate thing to go and realize it straight off. The Tramways Company of Alexandria was a purchase in order that we might arrange for extensions, so as to tap our own lands; but, apart from that altogether, the Tramways Company has been a most successful concern. It pays a steady dividend and the price of the shares at the present time is very much higher than it was when we bought them; in fact, we are very well pleased with the investment we have already made.

The proposal now is that this company be amalgamated with a company called the Building Lands of Egypt. This proposal has emanated entirely from the Egyptian shareholders. The first thing that we heard about this proposed amalgamation was practically in the month of April when a letter was addressed to us by a large number of Egyptian shareholders, asking us to convene this meeting in order that the amalgamation might be agreed to and carried through. Personally, before that date, I had no knowledge whatever on the Building Lands of Egypt. It is an Egyptian company, pure and simple, formed under the Egyptian laws, and, as far as I can understand, was formed very much about the same time as we formed our own company. The capital of that company-the Building Lands of Egypt-is £150,000, one half of which has been called up-that is £15,000. The first balance sheet, after this months working, has been published, and I see they paid a dividend at the rate of 5 per capt. per annum. On May 31 last the value of the properties of the Building Lands Company stood, after deducting various interests which were joined with their own, at £116,000. The lands which they held were valued at that sum. I have a list of the properties which this company owns, or has an interest in, and, of course, we have thy same schedule with regard to the properties of the Egyptian Trust and Investment; but in no case is it to the interest of either company that particulars should be made public with regard to such properties, having regard to the fact that they will be subject to realization hereafter. The shares of the Building Lands of Egypt are nominally £4 each, and the quotation for the shares on the Egyptian Bourse-of course, there is no quotation in London-is £5 10s., or 30s. premium. That was a quotation given to us in April last, and it is confirmed by a cable dated June 22, which states that the present buying price per share is - of the Building Lands of Egypt - £5 10s. for the £4 share. The shares of our company, the Egyptian Trust and Investment, as you are aware, have for some time past been in the neighborhood of about 10s. premium. The proposal in respect of the amalgamation in this that for every 10 shares held in the Egyptian Trust ard Investment Company three shares of the Building Lands of Egypt Company shall be given. The way that works out is, roughly, this: Three Building Lands shares of £1 each, selling at £5 10s, would mean £16 10s.; 10 Trust shares in our company, fully paid up, at 30s. each would be £ 5 In other words, taking the price of our shares at 10s. premium and the price of the Building Lands of Egypt at 30s. premium, at which they are selling, there is an improvement of profit to the shareholders in our company of about 3s. per phare. In other words, they are giving us 13s. premium instead of 10s, which is about the selling price. That is as nearly as possible the way it figures out. I mentioned to you just now that the shares in our company, with the premium, were of the value of 30s. each. We have only called op 10s. a share out of the £1; so that before any amalgamation is carried out it will be necessary to call up the other 10s., which would make the shares in our company fully paid.

Under ordinary circumstances, this company, the Egyptian Trust and Investment Company, would be holding its annual general meeting in a very short time, and we would have, probably, at this time, had it not been for the proposed amalgamation, been preparing our balance sheet; but in consequence of the amalgamation nothing has been done in respect of that at the present time, and practically since the end of April, when these proposals were made to us, matters have been to a certain extent in a state of suspended animation. I have told you the terms under which amalgamation is proposed. In addition, there are certain contracts, or certain clauses in the contracts, providing for compensation to the officers of the company, managers, secretary, and the directors. These are all in the contract of amalgamation, and will, if necessary, be read fully to the shareholder's here. I ought to remind you again, and I do so very clearly, that, this proposal for the amalgamation did not emanate from us; it emanated from the Egyptian shareholders, and it is well to remember that these Egyptian shareholders, out of a capital of 200,000 shares, hold, in all, should say, 180,000. You will no doubt, inquire from me, as shareholders, whether the proposed amalgamation is in our interests. That is, of course, the most important point of all. In respect to that matter, we can only give you the information we have got in regard to this Building Land of Egypt Company and the figures on which our information is based; but I think it is perfectly clear that the amalgamation is likely to be a benefit to both companies because there can be no doubt whatever that the land and the shares which we hold in Alexandria are of very great value. The estimated profit, as I mentioned to you just now, was the very large sum of £130,000, and as regards the Building Land Company, their profits, so far as their balance sheet shows are also of a very satisfactory character. They have engaged in practically the same sort of business and investment as we have been, the only difference being that we are an English company and they are purely an Egyptian company. This scheme of amalgamation has emanated, I have no doubt, to a considerable extent from members of our advisory board in Egypt. Mr. Glymenopoulo is the chief member of our advisory board in Egypt, and he is a director of the Building Lands of Egypt. The other directors are Messrs. Coury, Karam, Pikavachi, and Abdy--the latter an English gentleman whose name is extremely well known in Egypt. I know none of them, except Mr. Glymenopoulo and Mr. Abdy. I do not know that these Egyptian shareholders would have gone on buying our shares at 10s. premium, or would have gone on absorbing all these shares if they did not believe that the fortunes of the Building Lands of Egypt, after amalgamation, would have been even better than they had been before. As I told you, the £4 shares in the Building Lands of Egypt are worth £5 10s. There can be no doubt whatever that that is the correct price at the present time. That is all I can tell you with the materials before me; but the point is this and it is an all-important point: This meeting has been called by the Egyptian shareholders, and by shareholders holding over 100,000 shares, at least, and the proxies which these gentlemen have sent in in regard to this matter amount, I believe, as far as I know, to 98,000 shares out of the 200,000; so that it is quite evident that the Egyptian shareholders have got the matter to a considerable extent in their own hands. There is only one other matter I need trouble you about, and that is regarding a cable we have received this morning. We understand that a meeting of the Building Lands Company was held to-day. It was to be held on the same day as our meeting; bat, of course, there is a difference in time. We have got a cable which says: "At the Building Lands meeting all the resolutions were passed; but it is necessary that they be ratified by a second meeting within fifteen days.". Apparently, they have passed the resolution for amalgamation. The way they propose to do it is that we issue 60,000 shares to the liquidator of this company, and these 60,000 shares will be distributed in the proportion of three for ten to the shareholders of this company. They have passed the resolutions, and have also passed a resolution for amalgamation. I think that is really all I have got to say to you on the subject.

One thing I have omitted and that is that the Building Lands of Egypt, in order to ease guard to a certain extent the interests of any English shareholders to whom the shares in the Building Lands are allotted, have proposed that two of the directors of this board be placed on the Building Lands Company. Whether any of us will agree to that is quite another thing. It is obvious we could not attend all the meetings in Alexandria with the directors of the Building Lands of Egypt. With these remarks, gentlemen, I have to propose :(1) "That the proposed amalgamation with the Buildings Lands of Egypt is hereby approved, and that the directors be, and they are hereby, authorized and directed to any into effect the agreement read and explained to this meeting, which has been provisionally entered into for that purpose." (2) "That the provisional agreement dated May 21, 1906, providing for compensation of the directors and officers of the company be, and the same is hereby, approved." (3) "That the company be wound up voluntarily, and that George Thomas Broadbridge, the secretary of the company, be, and he is hereby, appointed liquidator for the purpose of such winding-up, at a fee of £210 and expenses."
Sir Gerard Smith seconded the resolution, and thereafter the Solicitor explained the salient points of the agreement.

The Chairman, in answer to a shareholder, said there were 15,000 shares, roughly, held by gentlemen on the English register. All the rest of the shares were bearer shares, held in Egypt. Of course, the 60,000 Building Lands shares would be distributed pro-rata. He might add that the Egyptian shareholders were extremely fond of having bearer warrants in respect of their shares. In order that they might have that, they had to pay up in full so, therefore, the vast majority of the shares in this company had been paid up in full by gentlemen in Egypt. As to the Alexandria Tramway dividend, he might state that the amount of dividend paid a few days ago was £2,466. They held 10,000 shares in that company.
A shareholder asked what became of the profit which might accrue after this date.
The Chairman said it simply went into the common pocket.

Mr. Thomas asked what became of the English shareholders who did not agree to transfer their shares to the Egyptian company. He thought all shareholders must have felt that while their affairs were in the hands of an English board they were very well satisfied, but they must all feel that while in the hands of an Egyptian board they could not have the same security.

The Chairman reminded the meeting that the Building Lands of Egypt had only called up £2 per share of the £4. Apparently the value of the property of that company was about £115,000. If that were the caseand it was given to him on the best authority- there was every reason why the shares of that company should be at a considerable premium. It was not a realized profit, but they had realized enough in six months to enable them to pay a dividend of 5 percent, and they expected to do very much better. As regarded the English shareholders, it was perfectly true there was no provision whatever for buying them out. The would have been very glad if any such vision had been made, but they could not stipulate for it. However, if shareholders chose, they could sell their shares in the Building Lands, and be thought it was only to be anticipated that the shares in Egypt would command, for some time to come, at least £5 10s., at which they were now selling; and if they got £5 10s. a share they not only got an equivalent to the premium in England, bat they got about 3s. a share more. If they did not choose to sell, then, in that case, they would simply have to remain as shareholders of the Building Lands Company.
A shareholder expressed the opinion that the company were not obtaining the full price for their shares.

The Chairman remarked that if any gentleman did not agree to come in he would get nothing at all, but if he sold now he would get the market price and his premium. The Egyptian shareholders, he went on to say, apparently wanted the control of this company in their own hands; indeed, there was one man in Egypt who could practically control the company, in virtue of his holding

Sir Gerald Smith hoped it would not go forth that shareholders deemed they were making a bad bargain, for, in fact, the Building Lands of Egypt were paying a twenty per cent, bonus, in addition to the par value.
The resolutions were then put to the meeting and carried.
On the motion of Mr. Thomas, and cordial vote of thanks was awarded the chairman for his conduct in the chair.
The proceedings then terminated.

div.head: PE-RU-NA KEEPS THE FAMILY IN THE BEST OF HEALTH
div.p: This is Only One of a Million of Homes in Which Pe-ru-na Has Been a Blessing. Read This Family's Glowing Testimony.

Mr. Henry S. Campbell, 1737 S. Williams St., Denver, Col., State Deputy of Modern Woodmen, Montana, and Delegate of Builders Trades Council, writes: "Peruna has been a blessing in our home. My wife was in poor health for several years and nothing but peruna helped her. She gradually recovered her health and became the mother of a boy which blessed out home. We call Gerald our Peruna boy. He is in the finest of health and his mother has never enjoyed such excellent health. "I have personally found Peruna of great value to me while travelling. Getting irregular meals and often poorly prepared food ruined my stomach, but Peruna toned up my digestive organs and brought fine health to me. "We are never without Peruna in our home and know by experience that it keeps us all in the best of health."
"We Call Gerald Our Pe-ru-na Boy. He Is In The Finest Health."

A RECENT LETTER: A recent letter received from Mr. and Mrs. Campbell is as follows: "We still use Peruna and in addition to our son, Gerald, who is a fat and saucy lad of 28 months , we have another son, still larger for his age. He is now ten months old and is always healthy. "His mother says Peruna has surely made both of our children as healthy as they are, helped, or course by Colorado's healhty air. "A bottle of Peruna is at all times a welcome visitor to our home." A multitude of families have discovered that Peruna is their standby. In all the catarrhal ailments which are likely to beset the remedy that brings quick relief. No matter whether it be a catarrhal condition of the head or lungs, or a derangement of the stomach and bowels, Peruna is the remedy.
Peruna- Once Used In The Family, Becomes a Permanent Fixture.

For special directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life ," a copy of which surrounds each bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty five shillings.

div.head: Theatre Alhambra. Les Cloches de Corneville
div.p: Hiel a eu lien la soirée au bénéfice de M. G. Piracciai. Tout Alexandrie avait tenu à mon. rer se sympathies bénéficiaire, aussi, at-cerlevant une salle comble que s'est déoulée l'aetion.

Nous connaissions déja M. Piraccioi comme in exellent comique, à qoi, tous les genres itaient familiere, il a tona à nous prouver hier qu'il etait un artiste au vrai sens da mot et que le drama lui seyait aussi bien que la soméde.

Ce fat one presque désillusion dans la salle oraqalon vit M, Piracoini dans le role da Fère aspald, mais, cette impression s'effacs bien rito eto'sat par an tonberra d'applaudiesements que se termina la scène da deuxième acte.
Vivement applaudie également la symphonie le Ssa, exéoutée par l'orchestre de San Stefano bas la direction da distingué chef d'orchestre M. Bracale.

La svirée s'est terminée par "L'histoire d'an Pierrot"; nous nous permettrons ici une petite ritiqop à l'adresa de Mme Calligaris, ou pla Ot da directeur artistique chargé de la distri Hvation des rôles: Pierrot a toajours eu la ré intation d'être un personnage hê ve, blême, au acies émacie ; Mme Calligaris, qui est l'ailler rs one excellente artiste, ne nous a pas aru remplir les conditions physiques indis onsables pour une semblable incarnation ; jerrot n's jamais été, croyons-nous, membre lela nyiété des 100 kilogs.

div.p: Le Caire Vendredi 6 Juillet 1906.
Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres reste

Hiet, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé onlais et demeure stationnaire à 87 7/8. L'U. lifiée 1 gagné 1/8 à 105. La National Bank st ratée invarié à 25 1/4, de même que l'agricole à 9 5/8, la Daïra à 16 7/8 et la Delta Light à 11 3/4.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Poncier Egyptien a aoturé à 757, son cours précédent. La Banque l'Athènes a baissé de 3 francs à 150.

Note marché des valeurs n'a brillé, ce natin, ni par l'animstion, ni par l'aotivité Janod calme, aveo transactions clairsemées. Les prix ont été toutefois bien soutenus et, à you d'exooptions près, il n'y a pas de difFéropola notables sigosler sur les cours d'hier.

La National Bank and gagné 1/16 à 25 5/16 3/8. La Agricole s'est raffermie à 9 9/16-5/8. La Casali Boonto a molli 214 l'action ancienne. La Binque d'Athènes a été cotée 153. LA Banqge d'Abyssinies baissé à 5 5/8.
Le Crédit Poncier faibli and 755. Le Wardan Estate rétrograde 5-6 1/16. L'Boterprise sod Development s'obt ihrerite á 12.
L'action Land Allotment a été bien tenue à 3 5/16 3/8; la part de fondateur, Assez resherchée, est remontée de 108 à 116.
La Delta laght progressé à 11 7/8. Les Jouissances Esox da Csire ont fléchi a 256257. Les Automobiles ont été offerts à 4 9/16.
Rien de particolier à relever dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, qui ont conservé leurs prix d'hier.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été offerts à 3 15/32. Les Hooker ont été ramenés à 1-1 1/32. Les parts de fondateur Estates sont revenues à 10 1/8 Les Glymeno poolo ont faibli à 17/16 et les Walker and Meimarachi à 0 5/8.11/16. Par contre, les Now Egyptian se sont tafte mis. 29 sh. 3, les Egyptian Coustractions 1 3/16, les Khedivial Mail32 sb. et la: Sacrerie, à 25 26

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land Co, convoquée pour le 19 Juillet à Londres, statuers, entre autre chose, sur la proposition de porter le capital social de £250,000 à £500,000 par une nouvelle émission d'actions, ainsi que d'étendre éventuelle ment les opérations de la Compagnie an Soudan.

Une nouvelle Société portant la dénomina tion de "Cotton Lands of Egypt" a été enre gislile Londres le 25 Juin dernier an capital de £440,886, 5 sh., représenté par 110,000 actions £4 et 7,725 parts de fondateur à 1 shelling.

L'objet de cette Compagnie est d'aquerir le sonrat intervenu entre la Société Anonyme do Behifra et un groupe financier egyptian con ante dans la Gharbiah. de 14,000 toddans des terrsin de calture faite par cette Société, et d'exploiter ce domaine.
L'Egyptian Trast and lavestment Ltd. G'ymenopoulos fait publier bier l'avis suivant oncernant les notions de cette société qui ne sont pas encore entièrement libérées :

"La direction de l'Egyptian Trust and Invastment Ltd. a l'honneur de prévenir les xotionnaires que le conseil d'administration vient de décider de faire un appel de 10 sh. par action, de telle sorte que les actions seront litérées entièrement d'une livre sterling.

"Les paiements devront s'effectuer à Alexandrie, le 21 Juillet 1906 pour le deuxième appel de 5 sh. at le 21 Août 1906 pour le troielème et dernier appel de 5 sh. Après ces dates, les retardataires seront passibles d'un intérêt de 7%

div.head: A Light Nourishment for General Use.
Allenburys' DIET
div.p: The "Allenburys" DIET is a complete milk and farinaceous Food, easy of assimilation, most agreeable to take, simply and quickly made. It is recommended in place of ordinary milk foods, gruel, etc., and whilst acceptable to all as a light nourishment, it is particularly helpful to Dyspeptics, Invalids and the Aged. In the sick-room it will be found invaluable and it is easily and quickly made, the addition of boiling water only being necessary.

The "Allenburys" DIET is readily digested by tose who are unable to take cow's milk and is particularly serviceable in convalescence. When taken as a light supper diet it will be found to promote tranquil and refreshing sleep. Although this DIET is a good for ADULTS and is entirely distinct fom the "Allenburys" Foods for Infants, yet it is also of great value as a restorative food for young children, especially during convalescence.
For Invalids, Dyspeptics & The aged.

div.head: Cotons.
div.p: Franchement on ne sait plus que penser, ni que diral de la façon dont les choses prooèdent chez nous pour ce qoi regarde la récolte aotoelle : chaque nouvelle baisse qui se produit, on oroitique l'on est au bout da chapelet et chaque fois c'est une nouvelle surprise qui vous est réservés pour le lendemain! Et cela bien ete notre cas pour la semaine qui vient de finir it qui avait étonné tout le monde avec na dépld table tente durant les trois premiers jours, qlo rien de nouveau de justifiait. Main, Avec ou sans raison, le fait matériel est que de Samedi || Mardi matin, c'est la faiblesse qui a domine en plein, en nous gratifiant d'une baisse (l'on demi tallari environ, le prix de 18 17/32 ayant été pratiqué sur l'annonce que la filière de Juillet, émise ce jour-là, était de 53,000 (antara. C'était trop; mais la peur, qui nous a fait faire tant de bévues oes temps der niers, ne raisonnait pas et il a falla Is oertitude que oetta filière venait d'être arrêtée par des gons qti étaient décidés à recevoir la mar: chandisli pour mettre fin à cette sorte de papique qui désorientait tous les intéressés dans l'aticle.

Pour comblo de malechanoe, on avait aussi répando discrétement le bruit, non prouvé d'ailleuse, que des spécalateurs du Caire hardis et inconscients étaient en train de a'amuser à vendre de l'Aout à découvert. Au fond, k nouvelle ne pouvait que gourire à nos haussies . Cause de la perspective on vue pour le jour où il serait falla racheter, maia di attendant, l'effet de ces ventes, dont on ignorait l'importance, a été de déprimer notre sarcbé.
Quoi qu'il en soit, niveau de 18 17/32, il y a un peu de soutien, ensuite un commenceu ent de reprise et fioalement clôture à 18 7/8.

Pourles deux jours suivanta il n'y a rien de particulier signaler, le marché s'étant con tonts de rester soutenu en pivotant autour da sosdit cours. Par contre, aujourd'hui e' d'une ben inattendue; une demande assez sérieund sorgie sur les mois courant et suivant, et portant aussi sur les filières Juillet, est venue noore point pour soulager des bési tants of ls conséquence en a été la bausse do Jailletla 19 3/16.- Toutefois, en előtare, il y and ea legère réaction par suite de quelques réalisations batives, mais à la cote de 19 3/32 le ton est resté soutend.

Comme résumé done, la semaine gagne 3/32 en tout ce qui n'est pas lourd à tout consi dérer ; pais ce qoi est plus important et qui mérite l'étre relevé, c'est que le changement d'allore parait désormais complet et que, nous Bommet peut être à la veille de commencer one série di séances régulières, sada soubresants et manipulations intempestiyes, mais qui pour rait biela nous, valoir une petite hausse graduelle it de nature à encourager les achetours Boa haitons-le, car en agissant de la sorte, or fipirait par attirer la filature et par effacer l'impression laissée par notre faiblesse des semaines précédentes et qui a fait que la conHommasion ne retarde ses achats que dana l'expoie de voir l'Aout lui offrir des chanosa aussi inespéréos que celles da Juillet. Cortes, la Goenlion de la liquidation de l'Aout viondra son lo tapis dara peu de jours, mais d'autre part, il ne fsat pas oublier qa'il p'exit plas do es positions ridioulement surchargées, cance des malheurs paarda, et que la qualité des détecteur d'à présent est tout autre que celle de ceux qui ont é:e forcés de liqaider løor Joillet à tout prix. Nous de voulons pas, par là, dire que l'on peut désor. mois faire ce que l'on 'veut, car nous sommes toujours de l'avia que tout mouvement exagé 6 serait fatal pour la fin; mais notre opinion est que, on soutenant raisonnablement les prix, avec les besoina incontestables qu'il y a à couvrir pour le restant de la camaagne, surtout en Angleterre où les approvisionnements touchent à leur fin, et avec les ressources plus quo modérées dont nous disposons, on pourrait bien finir par amoindrir les pertes que les erreurs du passé valent anjoord'hui 000X qui avaient cra à la posibi'ité de furoer la main à la filature, quel que soit le prix.

Contrairement à l'ancienne récolte, le No vembre a eu une tenue très satisfaisante Naturellement, un moment donné, quand les choses allaient mal, tout a été mis on avre pour l'écraser, mais malgré toos 198 efforts, le cours de 16 5/8 n'a pa etre c'esé. et ce qui a été très rema que, c'est qu'à chaque faiblesse pastagère que nous avons e e, les acheteurs se sont présentés plus nom breux sur le marché : On effirme même que le commerce d'exportation n'est pas resté indif férent devant les réactions et qu'il a opéré on exécution d'ordres qu'il avait sur la pro chaine campagne. Cela peut ê:te vrsi, quo. que, on dernier lieo, la réserve de la filatare ait persisté, étant donné que le nivean actuel n'étant pas de nature à rebater complet n.eu la consommation, de brio ou de bro, il y a toujours quelque chose à faire pour le debors.

En tous cas, la formeté de la nouvelle 16ooble semble avoir as raison d'être et cela poor plosieurs motifs. En premier lieu, les engagementa déjà pris par l'exportation sur octobre-janvier sont respectables et si les vendeurs sont con. verts en grande partie par des contrats,an food cette couverture n'est que du papier qu'il faudra bien finir par changer en marchandise effective aux dates d'embarquement. Cet bobange naturellement engendrera une forte demande sur le disponible et ce n'est certaine ment pas une pareille. circonstance qui provo quera la baisse. Sarement,à un moment donné, les arrivagea finiront par poser, mais cette date ent-elle dono ai rapprochée.

Comme deuxième raison, il y a le fait que nous entrerons dans la nouvelle campagne Aveo des réserves entièrement épuisées, qu'il faudra reconstituer et que cela ne pourra se faire dans les vingt-quatre heures. A tout prendre, et en admettant que pour la plus grande partie de ces besoins de commenco ment, la filature soit converte par des achats A livrer, il n'en est pas moins vrai encore que pour une portion il y aura dos achats à faire en disponible et que cela constitaora on surplos de demande qui aidera poor goelque temps au maintien des prix.

Quant à la théorie de la question de l'éoart entre Américains et égyptiens, il ne faut pas a'y attraper d'une façon absolue, l'expérience nous ayant déjà démontré plus d'une fois que ce qui est bon quand il y a pléthore de marchandise, disparait devant les besoins, sor tout de 000x des filateurs de fio ou des fabricants de spécialités.
Les points sur lesquels semblent s'appayer les baissiers pourront bien ne vérifier, maia très vraisemblablement ce ne sera qa's one date bloigode et si la récolto réussit en plein.
Encore une foie, il vaux mioux etre sobotour que vendeur.
Dernier cours do Novembre 16 23/32, tendance ferme.

Le marché da disponible a eu un semblant d'activité, car il y a ou quelques affaires et il s'en serait fait d'avantage sang la pénurie da oboix ; dans tous les ca', il y de la demande Tot elle porto aussi sur Ire marobanding base.
Quant aux prix, ils n'ont subi anoun chatRemont pendant la semaine; da resto, 1/8 près, la coto pour les contrats est la même qu'il y a buit jours.
Les exportations ont eté satisfaisantos Aveo leur total de 9800 Balles et pour la semaine prochaine les prévisions sont pour un chiffre pou près pareil, contre Bal 12,800 l'année passée.
Liverpool no nons a pas trop favorisés avec ses ventes journalières qui continuent sur la base de 100 sauf une seule exception en passant mais le petit atook et le peu de choix expliquent la chose.

Pour ce qui est des prix, le disponiblo perd 1/8 a la cote do 10 1/4 pour le fally good fair, tandis que les fators recalent de 5 et 4 points respectivement pour le juillet qui est à 9 53/64 ot pour le novembre coté à 8 38/64.
Pas beaucoup d'entrain aussi sur les Améri. cains et cela pour les causes déjà ex paées dans no pésé lentes revues.
Quant aux prix, le spot perd 2 points à 6.08 et les livrables 1 point aux coura de 576 pour le joillet août et 556 pour l'octobre novembre.

Comme nouvelle intéressante de l'Etranger, nous n'avons eu dans la semaine que le rapport da Borean d'Agriculture de Washington don. dant l'état de la plante comme étant de 83 3/10, contra 77 l'annéo pasado. Naturellement, les appréciations ont varié suivant la source d'où elles bunadaient, mais le fait réel est que ce rapport n'a prodoit aucun effe sur le mar. ché,ce qui équivaut à dire que les pors actuele de l'Américain sont coux qui de raient être. Tontefois, l'opinion générale penche à la basee a New York.
Nors donnons ci-après le résumé de Juin de la Produce Association. Il est favorable, mais au fond il ne dit rien auquel nous de sommes par babitués doette époque de l'année.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Le marché du disponible n'a présenté absoJument aucun intérêt pendant la semaine qui vient de finir, car, avec le manque praeque absola d'arrivages, il ne pouvait naturellement y vor den affaires en marchandise prête. Auss la cote a telle de constamment nominale; au plus bar, on a affiché P.T. 65 et comme clotore, nous sommes à P.T. 67.
Les exportations ont été petites et pour le restant de Jaillet il y a peu d'espoir pour le moment d'une amélioration sensible.

Hull avait énormément faibli et visait descendre au-dessous de £ 6 7/8 pour Juillet, mais devant le raffermissement de notre mar ché, elle est remontée à £6 8/9 acheteure. Pas beancoup d'affaires cependant.

Après etre tombe à P.T. 65, les contrata Joillet ont soudainement repris et finissent Ime à 67 1/10 Le changement est complet de la tendance et il a été motivé par une tomande de la part de l'exportation.
La fière do Juillet qui s'est élevée à ardebs 145,000, a vite été olasz éo et cola a soolagé lo marol é.
La nouvelle récolte reste ferme et arjoor d'hoi elle est montée à P.T. 63 1/2. LA tepdadoo est bonne et le marché est aotif.
Hull cote £ 6 2/6.

div.head: Constipation
div.p: To ensure a natural movement of the bowels, it is most important to take plenty of exercise every day. Many men and women don't do this, and they become more or less costive, sometimes going two or three days without a passage from the bowels. This is a very serious thing, not only because constipation makes our food and blood impure, but because the prolonged presence of waste matter in the bowels strains the muscular walls eventually paralyzing them, so that instruments have to be used to remove the impurities.

Those who cannot get enough exercise, or whose work is sedentary, should use Doans' Dinner Pills, which are made from pure roots and herbs that act on the bowels, invigorating the muscular walls and toning up the nerves, liver, stomach, and whole digestive organism. Doan's Dinner Pills soften the mass of clogging waste, preventing piles, and inflammation of the intestines; and they cure sluggish liver, indigestion, biliousness, headache, poor appetite, impoverished blood, and every symptom of liver, stomach, or bowel trouble.

Doan's Dinner Pills are sold by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 6 per box, or P.T. 30 for six boxes; or they may be bought direct from the general agent for Egypt, Max Fischer, Mousky Street, Cairo.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Après on début très calme nous avons eu cette semaine quelques marobés assez bons et une cloture satisfaisante.
Lundi, marché très calmo, preeqao toote la woote ost on baisse, les offres abondent, les demandes sont nalles ou à peu près.
Mardi, même marché qools yoilla ; les valeurs contingent à fléchir.
Mercredi, lo marobé présenté un peu plus d'animation que les jours précédents, la cote se relève.
Jeudi, le bon mouvement qui s'était mani. festé la veille no no contince point, le marobé est calme, los cours retombent.
Vendredi marché meilleur et sesez ferme.

Toujours cette même alternative de baat et de bus qui s'explique parfaitement, da raste. La morto saison ost maintenant dans son plein et un marché très soutenu aurait tout liou de nous étonner. Pour certaines valeurs, pourtant, la dépréciation notaelle est loin d'égaler cell des autides précédentes en cette saison.

Nous avons donné la semaino pasado, on apperon des cours de l'année dernière comparés a caux de l'aonée présente et nos lecteurs ont pa so rendre compte de la différenos sensible que l'on y rencontre. La plupart des grossos valeurs, ont atteint des cours vraiment tentants, ce qui fait comprendre la bansa sobito do oortains titres, bagno qui entraido sou vont les antrao valears on saite mais n'est malheurensement point durable.

Les marchés d'Europe sont généralement faibles. L'emprant irlandais, a présenté dos conditions tellement avantageuses que los portours de titres en Angleterre se sont empressés de réaliser leurs valeurs en portefeuille pour aoqaorir de l'empront, causant de os fait apo baisse assez forte à Londres.
Le marché de Paris est calme; les yeux sont tournés vers la Rossio et l'on oraint de se hazarder.
Ici la situation est saine, l'argent abondo et le taux d'intérêt a considérablement baissé ; la politique extérieure et la morte saison sont dono les segles causes de l'accalmio da marché.
L'Agricole, soutenue, débate landi à 9 9/16, baiare de 1/32 mardi,rovient à 9 9/16 mororedi, rodescend oncoro do 1/32 jeudi et o'tare an. oard'hui à 9 9/16.
La National Bank a 25 5/16 lundi, faiblit a 1/8 mardi, remonto de 1/8 a 25 1/4 mororedi, revient à 25 5/16 joudi ot so soutient vondrede a ce dernier cours.
Les Tramways d'Alexandrio, à 193 1/2 landi, perdent 1 fr. 50 mardi, remontent de 0 fr. 50 a 192 1/2 merprodi, sont soutenos 192 1/2 jeudi et bananent de 1 franc a 193 ½ anjourd'hui.
La Salt and Soda est inchangés durant toute la semaine et oote 19/6.
La Delta Land a été assez mouvementée lundi á 3 1/2 elle perd 3/32 and 3 13/32 mardi, remonto a 3 1/2 mercredi et revient à 3 15/32 jeudi et vendredi.

La Banque de Rome après avoir été nonten no jusqa' jeudi à 110 1/2 haosse brusquemment de 3 frs. 50 a 114 aujourd'hui. La Banque d'Athènes à 153 lundi et mardi, gagne 0 fr. 50 à 153 1/2 meroredi, faiblit de 0 fr. 25 a 153 1/4 joudi ot oltare apj vurd'hui a 153.
Relativement a l'aogmentation du capital et à la fasion de la banque d'Athènes, nous lisons dans l'Ecebomiste Européan :

"Les actionnaires de la Banque d'Athènes, Bon voqués en Assemblée générale extraordi. Daire, le 7 juillet proobain auront à statuer our l'aogmentation de capital do 20 a 40 millions de drachmes et le projet de fosion avec la Banque de Crédit Industriel de Grèce.
"Sur ces 200,000 actions nouvelles qui seront créées 110,000 seront remiens aux porteurs des 150,000 actions du Crédit lodostriel de Groor, en échange do lours propres titres.

"Le droit de sonacrire los 100,000 autres actions nouvelles sera réservé, a raison de 1 action pouvelle poar 2 ancienne, aux actionnaires actuels de la Banque d'Athènes qui agront, en outre, la facolté de noasorire, mais à titre réduotible, une quantité supplémentaire de titres, à leur convenance.

"Le succes de cette souscription ne saurait atre douteux, étant donné le prix avantageux auquel les nouvelles actions doivent être émises (on parle de 152 dr. 50, soit, au cours aotuel do change, 140 francs), la situation proapdro de la Banque d'Athènes et les brillantes perspectives d'avenir qui s'ouvrent de vant elle.

"L'opération projetés rovet, en effet, one importance partioulière et marquers une date dans l'existence da grand Etablissement. A meure que s'est amélioré le change hellénique et qe s'est développée la puissance doonomique et financière de la Grdos, la Banque Athènes, qui joué dans lo progrès de son pays on rólo remarquable, « vu s'acoroltre le volame de ses opérations et l'importanog do ses bénéficos.

"Deja par les succursales qu'elles établion, non seulement dans son propre pays, mais en Crète, en Egypte, a Constantinople et Smyre, ot, par les relations étroiten qu'elles liées aveo la bsata finsnon française, la Banque d'Athènes avait conqois on Orient une place prépondérante.
"L'absorption da Crédit Industriel de Grèce, qui était jusqu'à présent son principal concor rept, va aocrottre ses moyen d'action et forti. fiet endore la poissance de sa situation.
"Depuis a fondation, en 1893, son capital aura été porté, par augmentations successives, de 2,750,000 drachmas á 40,000,000.

"Lorsque sera réalisés la nouvelle augmentation projatée, le montant de son fondo de reserve hora de 9,000,000 de drachmas environ. "Le mouvement de onione est passé de 919 millions de drachmes · 1,721 millione, celui des opérations de bange de 58 1/9 millions 481 million.. Depuis 1901, søglemont, le mouvement des dépôts s'est flové do 139 millions 359 millions.

"Les résultats des quatro premiors mois do l'exercice 1906 montrent d'ailleurs que la prospérité de la Banque d'Athènes est en progres nion constante. Do Janvier à Avril inolosivement, les bénéfices ne sont élevés à 1,002,075 drachmes, contro 875,018 pour la période correapondante de 1905, soit une augmentation de 127,057 drachmes."

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
div.p: Resume des recues en Juin 1906

La température en Jaia a été chaude et pormale, et les cultares en ont largement profi.6. Sur ce point il n'y a eu des plaintes qoo dans le Nord de la Bébérs, on, on dornier lieu, qoolqoos nuits ont été platot fraiche.
L'état de la plante, aotaellement, som ble Otro satisfaisant, et, partant, los cotonnieroso présentent sous un aspect sain et vigoaroox.
Le retard précédemment constaté a été apasi on grande partie regagné et même, dans beaucoup d'endroits, il a completament disparo.

Des pontes de vors ont été trouvées dans Dombro do champs dana pre que toute los Provinoor, mais la chose n'est nollement générale et dans tous les cas l'effouillage recommandé par les mesures de précaution édiotées par le Gouvernement a été très effionce pour leur destruction. Do ce obef dono, acoun dégât à signalør pour le moment.
L'eau est soffi ante et même abondante, sauf dans qoe!ques localités isolées et éloignées on, comme chaque année, on aurait désiré ape irrigation plas copiedse.
Las renseignements de la Hanto Bgypto at da Payoom sont bons: il y bien un petit rotard sur l'année dernière, mais la planta est on très bon état, l'ona est abondante et pou do vers.

Contrairement aux premiers avia, l'acrdago a sabi une rédaction sonsible dans la province de Minieb, mais, d'autre part, l'augmentation qui a oa lieu ailleurs et notamment dans la province de Beni Bouef, offre une certaine compensation sur co point.

BUREAU DE PLACEMENT
Comptable expérimenté ayant des beuren disponibles désire tenir des Livros ou donner des leçons à des conditions avantageuser. Bonnes références.
Une grande maison anglaise de commerce a Alexandrio domanda on osissier appronti connaissant l'anglaie.
La même maison demando un bon employé connaissant aussi l'anglais pour as succursale au Caire. Une maison de Nouveautés demande un souschef bonnetier.
Une autre grande maison de détail demande un employé connaissant très bien le rayon chemiserie et bonneterie, et sachant la français et l'italien. Très belle situation.

Une maison de Port-Said demande un jeune homme connaissant bien le travail de bureau en général, les langues allemande et française, et si possible quelques notions d'anglais ; il aurait à assister à l'expédition des bateaux comme "shipping clerk."
Deux employés de grande Maison de Banque, disposant de quelques heures par jour, demandent à tenir des livres de commerce. Bonne références.
Un bon placier, au besoin comptable, connaissant le français, l'italien, l'allemand, l'arabo et la taro demande emploi.
Caissier comptable connaissant le français, l'anglais, le groo, lo turo et l'arménien demande emploi.
On demando un employé pour diriger impri meria.
Un bon eposinsour, connaissant la vente des drogueries, chercbe place, bonnes références.
Un professeur d'escrime demande place et au besoin à donner des leçons domicile.

Du demando un imprimeur pour soes pour diriger une imprimerie Agé de 30 et 80 ans, connaissant les langues. Une Maison de Commissione, demande un bon placier connaissant l'Araba et diversos lan. gues, bon traitement. Do demande pour Port-Said un joune homme de vingt ans environ, connaisant le français et l'anglais et ayant travaillé dans une librairio; lo logement est fourni par la mai son. Adresser demande avec références ainsi que les appointements désirés.
N.B.- Pour tous renseignements s'adresser Siège social de la Société, Rue Mosquée Attarine No. 21.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
